question: Do both osteoarthritis and polymyalgia rheumatica cause joint stiffness?
generated_answer: Yes, both osteoarthritis and polymyalgia rheumatica can cause joint stiffness. Osteoarthritis, a common form of arthritis, is characterized by stiffness and pain in the joints due to wear and tear on the cartilage. Polymyalgia rheumatica, an inflammatory disorder, causes muscle pain and stiffness, particularly in the neck, shoulders, and hips.
ground_truth_answer: Yes, both conditions cause joint stiffness, but in different ways. In osteoarthritis, joint stiffness is one of the irreversible symptoms that appears after the disease has progressed. In polymyalgia rheumatica, stiffness is a primary symptom, particularly affecting the neck, shoulders, and hips, and is most severe in the morning or after periods of inactivity, typically lasting longer than 30 minutes.
